item.title: Chapter 1: Theseus
item.description:
Plutarch PLOO-tark ’s Life of Theseus THEE-see-us

(Retold for Young Readers)

Plutarch PLOO-tark Speaks

English
Plutarch PLOO-tark says: when we write about heroes of long ago, we step into the land of myths (miths)—old stories that are part truth, part tale. Map‑makers, when they reached unknown places, used to write things like “Here live wild beasts” or “Here is endless ice.” In the same way, we must admit when a story is more wonder than history.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
Theseus THEE-see-us , hero of Athens ATH-ens , is often compared to Romulus ROH-myoo-lus , hero of Rome ROHM . Both were said to be sons of gods, both built great cities, both had famous adventures, and both died in tragedy.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Early Life

English
Theseus THEE-see-us ’s father was Aegeus EE-jee-us , king of Athens ATH-ens . His mother was Aethra EE-thrah , daughter of King Pittheus PIT-thee-us of Troezen TROH-zen .
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
Aegeus EE-jee-us had no children, so he asked the oracle (OR‑ah‑cul)¹ at Delphi DEL-fee for advice. The oracle spoke in riddles: “Do not loosen the mouth of the wineskin until you come again to Athens ATH-ens .”
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
King Pittheus PIT-thee-us guessed what it meant and arranged for Aegeus EE-jee-us to be with his daughter. Before Aegeus EE-jee-us left, he placed a sword and sandals under a huge rock and told Aethra EE-thrah : “If our son grows strong enough to lift this stone, let him take these things and come to Athens ATH-ens . Then I will know he is mine.”
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
When Theseus THEE-see-us grew into a strong young man, he easily lifted the rock and took the sword and sandals. His mother begged him to go by sea—because the land road was full of bandits (BAN‑dits)² and monsters. But Theseus THEE-see-us wanted to prove himself, like the hero Heracles HER-uh-kleez . He chose the dangerous road.
Español
[ES placeholder]

The Labors of Theseus

English
On his journey, Theseus THEE-see-us cleared the land of evil men:
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
Periphetes PAIR-ih-FEE-teez , the Club‑Bearer. Theseus THEE-see-us killed him and kept his wooden club as his weapon.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
Sinis SEE-nis , the Pine‑Bender. He bent trees and tied people to them until they snapped back and tore them apart. Theseus THEE-see-us defeated him in the same way.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
The Crommyonian KROM-ee-oh-nee-an Sow (a wild pig—or a cruel woman nicknamed “Sow”). Theseus THEE-see-us killed it.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
Sciron SKY-ron , who made travelers wash his feet and then kicked them into the sea. Theseus THEE-see-us threw him from the cliff.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
Cercyon SIR-see-on , a wrestler who killed all challengers. Theseus THEE-see-us wrestled and beat him fairly.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
Procrustes proh-KRUS-teez , the Stretcher, who forced strangers to fit his iron bed by cutting or stretching them. Theseus THEE-see-us gave him the same fate.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
By these deeds, Theseus THEE-see-us became famous as a bringer of justice (JUS‑tis)³.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Arrival in Athens

English
When Theseus THEE-see-us reached Athens ATH-ens , Medea meh-DAY-ah , the king’s wife, feared him. She tried to poison him at a banquet. But just as he lifted the cup, Aegeus EE-jee-us saw the sword Theseus THEE-see-us carried and knew him as his son. He dashed the poison away and welcomed Theseus THEE-see-us as heir.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
The fifty sons of Pallas PAL-las plotted against Theseus THEE-see-us , but he defeated them.
Español
[ES placeholder]

The Marathonian Bull

English
Theseus THEE-see-us captured the great bull of Marathon MARE-ah-thon , showed it alive to the people, and sacrificed it to Apollo ah-PAH-loh , the god of light and music.
Español
[ES placeholder]

The Minotaur and Ariadne

English
Athens ATH-ens was forced to send seven boys and seven girls every nine years to Crete KREET . There, they were devoured by the Minotaur MIN-oh-tor , a monster half‑man, half‑bull, kept inside the Labyrinth LAB-ih-rinth ⁴.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
Theseus THEE-see-us volunteered to go. In Crete KREET , Princess Ariadne air-ee-AD-nee fell in love with him. She gave him a ball of thread. Theseus THEE-see-us unwound it as he walked through the twisting passages, so he could find his way back. He killed the Minotaur MIN-oh-tor and led the children out safely.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
He sailed away with Ariadne air-ee-AD-nee , but left her behind on the island of Naxos NAK-sos . On the return, he forgot to change his sail (SAYL) from black to white. King Aegeus EE-jee-us , waiting on the cliffs, saw the black sail and thought his son dead. In grief, he threw himself into the sea—ever after called the Aegean ee-JEE-an Sea.
Español
[ES placeholder]

King of Athens

English
Theseus THEE-see-us now ruled Athens ATH-ens . He united the many small towns of Attica AT-ih-kah into one city. He started the Panathenaic pan-ATH-en-ay-ik festival⁵, created tribes, and gave laws. He shared power with the nobles and the people, no longer ruling as a single king. This, Plutarch PLOO-tark says, was his greatest act.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Later Adventures

English
Theseus THEE-see-us fought the Amazons AM-ah-zons , women warriors. He married their queen, some say Antiope AN-tee-oh-pee , others say Hippolyta hi-PAHL-ih-tah . The Amazons AM-ah-zons later invaded Athens ATH-ens but were defeated.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
He joined Heracles HER-uh-kleez in his adventures.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
With his friend Peirithous pie-RITH-oh-us , he carried off young Helen HEL-en (later Helen HEL-en of Troy TROI ). Together they rashly tried to kidnap Persephone per-SEF-oh-nee , queen of the underworld. There they were trapped. Peirithous pie-RITH-oh-us never escaped, but Heracles HER-uh-kleez freed Theseus THEE-see-us .
Español
[ES placeholder]

Decline and Death

English
When Theseus THEE-see-us came back, the Athenians no longer loved him as before. He lost power and sailed to the island of Scyros SKY-ros . There, King Lycomedes lie-KOM-ee-deez pushed him from a cliff, killing him.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Honors After Death

English
Long years later, the Athenians brought back his bones and buried them in their city. They built him a hero’s shrine (SHRYNE)⁶ and honored him as a protector of the weak. In battles, some said they even saw his spirit fighting for Athens ATH-ens .
Español
[ES placeholder]

Footnotes

English
Oracle – A place where a god’s message was spoken, often in riddles.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
Bandit – A robber who attacked travelers.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
Justice – Fair treatment, giving people what is right.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
Labyrinth – A giant maze of twisting halls and passages.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
Festival – A special holiday with sacrifices, games, and music.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
Shrine – A holy place to honor a god or hero.
Español
[ES placeholder]

item.title: Chapter 2: Romulus
item.description:
Plutarch PLOO-tark ’s Life of Romulus ROH-myoo-lus

(Retold for Young Readers)

Plutarch PLOO-tark Speaks

English
Plutarch PLOO-tark tells us that Romulus ROH-myoo-lus , the first king of Rome ROHM , is a good match for Theseus THEE-see-us , the founder of Athens ATH-ens . Both were born in mystery, both fought great battles, both built cities, and both vanished strangely at the end of their lives.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Birth and Early Life

English
The story begins with Aeneas ee-NEE-us , the Trojan hero who fled Troy TROI and came to Italy. His descendants became kings of Alba Longa AL-bah LON-gah , an old Latin city.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
In this line was Numitor NOO-mi-tor , who was cheated of his throne by his brother Amulius ah-MYOO-lee-us . Amulius ah-MYOO-lee-us forced Numitor NOO-mi-tor ’s daughter Rhea Silvia REE-ah SIL-vee-ah to serve as a Vestal Virgin (VES-tal VIR-jin)¹ so she could not marry. But she was said to be with child by Mars MARZ , the god of war. She gave birth to twin boys, Romulus ROH-myoo-lus and Remus REE-mus .
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
Amulius ah-MYOO-lee-us ordered the babies to be drowned in the river Tiber TIE-ber . But the cradle floated to shore. There, a she‑wolf came and nursed the infants. Later, a shepherd named Faustulus FAW-stoo-lus found them and raised them with his wife.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
The twins grew strong, brave, and restless. They led bands of young men, fighting robbers and protecting shepherds. At last they learned who they truly were—the grandsons of Numitor NOO-mi-tor . They killed Amulius ah-MYOO-lee-us , restored their grandfather to the throne, and then set out to build a new city of their own.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Founding of Rome ROHM

English
The brothers quarreled about where to build and who should rule. They agreed to ask for a sign from the gods by augury (AW-gur-ee)²—watching birds in the sky.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
Remus REE-mus saw six vultures first, but Romulus ROH-myoo-lus claimed to see twelve. They argued, and in the fight, Remus REE-mus was killed. Some say Romulus ROH-myoo-lus struck him; others say Remus REE-mus leapt over Romulus ROH-myoo-lus ’s half‑built walls in mockery, and Romulus ROH-myoo-lus killed him in anger.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
Thus Romulus ROH-myoo-lus became the sole founder and named the city Rome ROHM after himself.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Building the City

English
Romulus ROH-myoo-lus gathered people by declaring an asylum (ah-SIGH-lum)³ in the new city. All who came—runaway slaves, exiles, wanderers—were welcomed. This filled Rome ROHM with a bold but rough people.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
He divided them into tribes, and into curiae (KYUR-ee-eye)⁴ (small groups for voting and feasts). He chose one hundred leading men, called senators (SEN-ah-tors)⁵, who became the council of Rome ROHM .
Español
[ES placeholder]

The Sabine Women

English
Rome ROHM had many men but few women. To give his people wives, Romulus ROH-myoo-lus invited the neighboring Sabines SAY-bynz to a festival. At a signal, the Romans seized the Sabines SAY-bynz women and carried them off as brides.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
The Sabines SAY-bynz men were furious and went to war. At first, the Romans fought alone, but soon the women themselves ran between the armies. With babies in their arms, they begged their fathers and husbands not to kill each other.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
Their courage brought peace. The Sabines SAY-bynz and Romans joined into one people, and Romulus ROH-myoo-lus ruled together with the Sabine SAY-byn king Tatius TAY-shus .
Español
[ES placeholder]

Kingship and Laws

English
Romulus ROH-myoo-lus ruled wisely for a time. He gave laws, honored the gods, and rewarded bravery in war. He created the legions (LEE-juns)⁶, groups of fighting men, and gave each legion a banner.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
He made rules for the army, for marriage, and for the worship of the gods. He gave the conquered people part of the land and made them citizens. This helped Rome ROHM grow stronger.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Death of King Tatius TAY-shus

English
One day King Tatius TAY-shus was accused of unfairly protecting some of his men who had committed crimes. When he visited the city of Lavinium lah-VIN-ee-um , he was killed in revenge.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
Romulus ROH-myoo-lus was now the sole king again. He grew prouder and harsher, ruling like a warlord. Some loved him still, but others feared him.
Español
[ES placeholder]

The Strange Death of Romulus ROH-myoo-lus

English
One day, Romulus ROH-myoo-lus gathered the people at the Field of Mars MARZ to review the army. Suddenly a storm with thunder and darkness fell. When it cleared, Romulus ROH-myoo-lus was gone.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
Some said he was taken up to heaven by his father Mars MARZ and became a god, Quirinus kwee-REE-nus . Others whispered that the senators had killed him in the storm and cut his body into pieces.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
The people mourned, but later a nobleman swore that Romulus ROH-myoo-lus appeared to him, shining and taller than before. Romulus ROH-myoo-lus , he said, commanded the Romans to be brave and to rule the world.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
So they built him a temple and honored him as the god Quirinus kwee-REE-nus .
Español
[ES placeholder]

Closing

English
Thus lived and died Romulus ROH-myoo-lus , first king of Rome ROHM . He and his brother Remus REE-mus began in danger, suckled by a wolf, and rose to found a city. His deeds were bold, his rule was fierce, and his end mysterious. Rome ROHM remembered him forever as their founder and as a god.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Footnotes

English
Vestal Virgin – A woman sworn to serve the goddess Vesta, tending her sacred fire and living unmarried.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
Augury – Reading the will of the gods by watching the flight of birds.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
Asylum – A safe place where runaways or strangers could find protection.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
Curiae – Small groups of Roman citizens used for voting and gatherings.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
Senators – The council of older men who advised the king and later ruled Rome ROHM .
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
Legion – A large group of Roman soldiers, the main unit of the army.
Español
[ES placeholder]

item.title: Chapter 3: Comparison — Theseus and Romulus
item.description:
Comparison of Theseus THEE-see-us and Romulus ROH-myoo-lus

(Retold for Young Readers)

English
Plutarch PLOO-tark says: now that we have told the lives of Theseus THEE-see-us and Romulus ROH-myoo-lus , we must set them side by side, to see how they are alike and how they are different.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Births and Families

English
Theseus THEE-see-us was said to be the son of a mortal king, Aegeus EE-jee-us , or of Poseidon puh-SY-don , the god of the sea. Romulus ROH-myoo-lus was said to be the son of a Vestal Virgin and the war god Mars MARZ . Both, then, had claims of divine fathers, and both were born in secret, with danger over their heads from the very beginning.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Early Adventures

English
Theseus THEE-see-us chose the dangerous road and killed robbers, clearing the land of monsters. Romulus ROH-myoo-lus fought his uncle Amulius ah-MYOO-lee-us , freed his grandfather Numitor NOO-mi-tor , and rescued a throne. So each showed courage: one by fighting wild men along the road, the other by daring to strike down a king.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Founding of Cities

English
Theseus THEE-see-us united many towns into one great city, Athens ATH-ens , giving laws and festivals and sharing power. Romulus ROH-myoo-lus founded a brand‑new city, Rome ROHM , giving it walls, tribes, senators, and laws. It is greater to create a city out of nothing, as Romulus ROH-myoo-lus did, Plutarch PLOO-tark says, than to combine cities already there, as Theseus THEE-see-us did. But Theseus THEE-see-us , by giving up his power and sharing rule, showed more gentleness and wisdom.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Deeds with Women

English
Theseus THEE-see-us carried off women in several adventures: Helen HEL-en when she was young, and the Amazons AM-ah-zons who later invaded Athens ATH-ens . Romulus ROH-myoo-lus seized the Sabine SAY-byn women, but did so not for lust but to give his people wives and to make peace through their children. So in this, Romulus ROH-myoo-lus ’s deed had more justice, and Theseus THEE-see-us ’s more recklessness.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Wars and Bravery

English
Both fought many battles and brought strength to their cities. Theseus THEE-see-us had the glory of defeating monsters like the Minotaur MIN-oh-tor and the Amazons AM-ah-zons . Romulus ROH-myoo-lus had the glory of conquering peoples around him and making Rome ROHM strong.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Deaths

English
Theseus THEE-see-us died in exile, betrayed by King Lycomedes lie-KOM-ee-deez , and not honored until long after. Romulus ROH-myoo-lus vanished in a storm, some believing he was taken to the gods, others that he was slain by his own men. Plutarch PLOO-tark says: Romulus ROH-myoo-lus ’s end was more glorious, if we believe he became a god. But Theseus THEE-see-us ’s end was more pitiful, though later his people gave him honor.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Final Judgment

English
Both men were bold, both were founders, both were remembered forever. But if we must choose: Romulus ROH-myoo-lus was greater in war and founding a city. Theseus THEE-see-us was gentler in laws and sharing power. So each has his crown: Romulus ROH-myoo-lus for strength, Theseus THEE-see-us for wisdom.
Español
[ES placeholder]

item.title: Chapter 4: Lycurgus
item.description:
Plutarch PLOO-tark ’s Life of Lycurgus lye-KUR-gus

(Retold for Young Readers)

Plutarch PLOO-tark Speaks

English
Plutarch PLOO-tark tells us that Lycurgus lye-KUR-gus , the lawgiver of Sparta SPAR-tuh , can be compared with Numa NOO-muh , the lawgiver of Rome ROHM . Both were remembered for giving laws, not for conquering lands. But Lycurgus lye-KUR-gus made his people hard and warlike, while Numa NOO-muh made his people gentle and peaceful.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Birth and Early Life

English
Lycurgus lye-KUR-gus was said to be a descendant of Heracles HER-uh-kleez . His family ruled in Sparta SPAR-tuh , a city in Greece famous for its warriors. When the king, his brother, died, the throne should have gone to the king’s young son. Until that boy grew up, Lycurgus lye-KUR-gus served as guardian of both the boy and the kingdom. Some people whispered that Lycurgus lye-KUR-gus wanted the throne for himself. To avoid suspicion, he left Sparta SPAR-tuh and traveled far away.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Travels and Learning

English
Lycurgus lye-KUR-gus went first to Crete KREET , where he studied their laws and customs. He met wise men like Thales THAY-leez , who taught through songs and poetry but really gave political advice. From Crete KREET he sailed to Asia Minor and studied the wealth and luxury of the Ionians eye-OH-nee-anz . He disliked their soft living. Later he even visited Egypt and, some say, even India, always learning how other nations lived and governed.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Return to Sparta SPAR-tuh

English
When Lycurgus lye-KUR-gus returned, he brought bold new ideas. Sparta SPAR-tuh was troubled by quarrels and greed. Rich men had too much, poor men too little. Lycurgus lye-KUR-gus wanted to make all Spartans equal. First he divided the land into equal lots—nine thousand for Spartan citizens and thirty thousand for the surrounding free people, called Perioeci PAIR-ee-oh-sigh . Each piece of land gave just enough grain, oil, and wine to support a family. He also took away gold and silver money. Instead, he made heavy iron bars the only money. They were so bulky that no one could carry much, and thieves had nothing worth stealing. This change ended greed for riches.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Simple Living

English
Lycurgus lye-KUR-gus wanted no fancy furniture, no silver cups, no gold jewelry. He ordered all to eat at common meals, called syssitia sis-SIT-ee-uhs ¹. Men and boys ate together in groups. Everyone had plain food—mostly barley, black broth, cheese, and little meat. Guests could be invited, but not often. He even made the women exercise—running, wrestling, and throwing the discus—so they would be strong mothers of strong children. Marriage, too, was carefully arranged, and men were not allowed to marry too late in life.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Raising Children

English
In Sparta SPAR-tuh , children belonged to the city as much as to their parents. When a baby was born, elders inspected it. If the child was healthy, it was raised; if weak, it was sadly left to die on a hillside. Boys were trained from seven years old in groups. They lived in barracks, went barefoot, wore one cloak all year, and slept on reeds. They learned to endure hunger, pain, and hardship. To sharpen their wits, they were encouraged to speak briefly and wisely—this became known as “ Laconic la-KON-ik ”² speech.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Laws and Government

English
Lycurgus lye-KUR-gus also re‑shaped Sparta SPAR-tuh ’s government. He created a council of elders, called the Gerousia geh-ROO-see-uh ³, made up of wise men over sixty. He balanced power between the kings, the council, and the people’s assembly. Later, ephors EH-fors ⁴, a board of five overseers, were added. To make the laws respected, he said they came from the god Apollo ah-PAH-loh at Delphi DEL-fee . People called them rhetras RAY-trahs ⁵—divine commands.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Lasting Peace at Home

English
When Lycurgus lye-KUR-gus saw his reforms were accepted, he bound the people by an oath not to change anything until he returned. Then he went on a journey, never to come back. Some say he died in Crete KREET , others in Delphi DEL-fee . His body, they say, was burned and the ashes scattered into the sea, so Spartans could not claim he had returned and break their oath.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Closing

English
Lycurgus lye-KUR-gus gave Sparta SPAR-tuh its famous way of life: equal land, iron money, common meals, hard training, and strict laws. His people became fearless warriors, living simply, speaking wisely, and putting the city above themselves. Though he died far away, his laws lived on for centuries, making Sparta SPAR-tuh one of the most admired—and feared—cities of Greece.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Footnotes

English
Syssitia – Common mess halls where Spartan men and boys ate together.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
Laconic speech – Short, sharp sayings; from “Laconia,” the region of Sparta SPAR-tuh .
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
Gerousia – Council of elders over sixty who advised the kings.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
Ephors – Five officials elected each year to oversee laws and daily life.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
Rhetras – Ancient laws or sayings claimed to come from the god Apollo ah-PAH-loh .
Español
[ES placeholder]

item.title: Chapter 5: Numa
item.description:
Plutarch PLOO-tark ’s Life of Numa NOO-muh

(Retold for Young Readers)

Plutarch PLOO-tark Speaks

English
Plutarch PLOO-tark says that Numa NOO-muh , the second king of Rome ROHM , can be compared with Lycurgus lye-KUR-gus of Sparta SPAR-tuh . Lycurgus lye-KUR-gus made his people fierce and warlike; Numa NOO-muh made his people peaceful and gentle.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Birth and Early Life

English
Numa NOO-muh was born in Sabine SAY-bine country, a land northeast of Rome ROHM . He was known for wisdom and goodness even as a boy. He studied nature, honored the gods, and lived simply. When Romulus ROH-myoo-lus , the first king of Rome ROHM , died in a strange way, the people argued about who should rule. At last, both Romans and Sabines SAY-bynz agreed: Numa NOO-muh was the right man. He was forty years old when the messengers came and asked him to be king. At first, he refused. He said power brought envy and danger. But his father and friends persuaded him. They told him he could turn Rome ROHM from war to peace.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Numa NOO-muh Becomes King

English
Numa NOO-muh entered Rome ROHM with sacrifice and prayer. The priests looked for signs from the gods—birds in flight, thunder, and fire. When the omens were good, Numa NOO-muh took the crown.
Español
[ES placeholder]

A King of Peace

English
Rome ROHM had been founded by bold warriors. Its people were restless and fiery. Numa NOO-muh wanted to soften them. He forbade unnecessary wars. He built temples, started sacrifices, and led great processions with music and dancing. He told stories of visions and voices from the gods, which made the people respect him. Some said he was taught by the nymph Egeria eh-JEER-ee-ah , a goddess of springs, who guided him at night.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Laws and Priests

English
Numa NOO-muh organized religion in Rome ROHM . He created many priestly orders: Pontifices PON-tif-ih-sees ¹—high priests to guide all sacred duties; Flamines FLAH-min-eez ²—special priests to serve certain gods like Jupiter, Mars, and Quirinus kwee-REE-nus ; and Vestal Virgins VES-tal VIR-jinz ³—maidens to guard the holy fire of Vesta. He gave the Vestals great honor. If one passed by, even a criminal on his way to death could be spared. Numa NOO-muh built the temple of Vesta, the Regia REE-jee-ah or king’s house, and many shrines. He taught that the gods had no human shape. For a hundred and seventy years after him, Romans worshipped without statues.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Sacred Customs

English
Numa NOO-muh made sacrifices gentle, not bloody. He asked for flour, wine, and small gifts instead of animal killings. He wanted people to honor the gods with pure hearts. He taught that the city should rest during ceremonies. No hammering, shouting, or clattering was allowed in the streets when holy processions passed. The Romans kept this custom for centuries.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Tales of Magic and Wonders

English
Stories grew around Numa NOO-muh . One tale said he trapped the woodland spirits Picus PIE-kus and Faunus FAW-nus by mixing wine and honey in a spring. They, or Jupiter himself, taught him charms against thunder and lightning—using onions, fish, and bits of hair. Another story told how he invited citizens to a simple meal. Suddenly, the room filled with gold cups and fine dishes. He said the goddess Egeria eh-JEER-ee-ah had brought them. People believed his power came from the gods.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Family and Death

English
Numa NOO-muh married Tatia TAY-shah , daughter of the Sabine SAY-bine king Tatius TAY-shus . Later, he was said to have loved the nymph Egeria eh-JEER-ee-ah , who counseled him. He lived a long, quiet life, ruling justly for forty‑three years. He died over eighty years old. Rome ROHM mourned him deeply, as if each person lost a dear relative. His body was placed in a stone tomb under the Janiculum juh-NIK-yuh-lum hill. In another tomb beside it, he left his sacred books, written with his own hand.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Closing

English
Thus Numa NOO-muh , the second king of Rome ROHM , turned a city of warriors into a city of laws and worship. He gave the people priests, sacrifices, and holy customs. He taught them peace, justice, and reverence. Rome ROHM remembered him not for conquest, but for wisdom and piety.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Footnotes

English
Pontifices – Chief priests who oversaw all Roman religion.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
Flamines – Priests assigned to serve a single god, like Mars or Jupiter.
Español
[ES placeholder]
English
Vestal Virgins – Maidens chosen to guard the sacred fire of Vesta, goddess of the hearth.
Español
[ES placeholder]

item.title: Chapter 6: Comparison — Lycurgus and Numa
item.description:
Comparison of Lycurgus lye-KUR-gus and Numa NOO-muh

(Retold for Young Readers)

Plutarch PLOO-tark Speaks

English
Now that we have heard the lives of Lycurgus lye-KUR-gus of Sparta SPAR-tuh and Numa NOO-muh of Rome ROHM , let us see how they compare.
Español
[ES placeholder]

How They Were Alike

English
Both men were famous not for conquering lands, but for shaping their people with laws. Both made their citizens live with discipline. Both claimed help from the gods— Lycurgus lye-KUR-gus from Apollo ah-PAH-loh at Delphi DEL-fee , Numa NOO-muh from the goddess Egeria eh-JEER-ee-ah . Both taught that laws must be obeyed for the sake of the whole city.
Español
[ES placeholder]

How They Were Different

English
But they were not the same in spirit. Lycurgus lye-KUR-gus trained his people to be soldiers. His laws made Spartans hard, brave, and ready for war. He took away wealth, forced all to live simply, and raised boys to endure pain and hunger. Numa NOO-muh , instead, taught peace. He stopped wars, built temples, and filled Rome ROHM with sacred rites. He turned fiery warriors into gentle worshippers, teaching them to honor the gods with prayer and sacrifice.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Different Kinds of Kingship

English
Lycurgus lye-KUR-gus ruled first as a guardian, then gave his city laws, and finally left so they would keep them. He used force at times, even risking his life, but he created a system where rich and poor were equal. Numa NOO-muh ruled as a king by choice of the people. He never used force. His power rested on persuasion and religion. He made Rome ROHM just and peaceful without fighting or bloodshed.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Which Was Greater?

English
Plutarch PLOO-tark says: Lycurgus lye-KUR-gus showed more strength of character, for he tamed a fierce city by law and discipline. Numa NOO-muh showed more gentleness, for he turned a city of fighters toward peace and piety. Each was great in his own way— Lycurgus lye-KUR-gus in bravery, Numa NOO-muh in wisdom. Together, they remind us that a city needs both courage and justice to last.
Español
[ES placeholder]

item.title: Chapter 7: Solon
item.description:
Plutarch PLOO-tark ’s Life of Solon SOH-lon

(Retold for Young Readers)

Plutarch PLOO-tark Speaks

English
Plutarch PLOO-tark tells us that Solon SOH-lon , the wise lawgiver of Athens ATH-ens , can be compared with Publicola poo-BLIK-oh-lah of Rome ROHM . Both were praised for giving laws and saving their cities.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Early Life

English
Solon SOH-lon was born into a noble but not very rich family in Athens ATH-ens . He loved learning and poetry; his verses showed wisdom and courage. He became respected for his honesty and skill with words. Athens ATH-ens in his time was troubled: the rich had much land and power; the poor fell into debt, and some even had to sell themselves or their children as slaves. Anger grew, and the city was close to civil war.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Solon SOH-lon ’s Rise

English
The people trusted Solon SOH-lon to lead them. Both rich and poor hoped he would give them fairness. Some even urged him to become tyrant—a single ruler with absolute power. But Solon SOH-lon refused. He said tyranny was sweet at first but had no safe way down. He wanted freedom, not tyranny.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Wars and Poetry

English
Before he became lawgiver, Solon SOH-lon fought for Athens ATH-ens . He led the struggle with Megara MEG-ah-rah over the island of Salamis SAL-ah-miss . Athens ATH-ens had given up the fight, but Solon SOH-lon wrote bold poems urging them to try again. Inspired, the Athenians followed him, they won Salamis SAL-ah-miss , and Solon SOH-lon gained fame as a patriot and poet.
Español
[ES placeholder]

The Disburdenment

English
As lawgiver, Solon SOH-lon ’s first act was the Seisachtheia say-sak-THEE-ah ¹, or “Disburdenment.” He cancelled debts and freed those enslaved for owing money. He forbade loans on a person’s body. This gave the poor a new start. The rich were angry—they lost their security. The poor were angry too—they had wanted land divided equally. But Solon SOH-lon stood firm: he gave justice, not favors. Soon the city calmed, and people honored him.
Español
[ES placeholder]

New Laws and the Constitution

English
Solon SOH-lon was asked to reshape all of Athens ATH-ens . He repealed the harsh laws of Draco DRAY-ko , except for those against murder, because Draco DRAY-ko had punished almost every crime with death. Solon SOH-lon said such severity was unfit. He divided Athenians into four classes by wealth: the richest could hold the highest offices; the middle ranks had lesser offices; the poorest could not hold office, but they could vote in the assembly and serve on juries. He also created the Council of Four Hundred to prepare business for the people’s assembly, and he gave power to courts so even the poor could challenge the mighty.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Wisdom and Travels

English
Solon SOH-lon knew his laws would displease both sides. To keep them steady, he made the people swear to obey them for ten years, then he left Athens ATH-ens to travel. He visited many places. In Lydia LID-ee-uh , he met King Croesus KREE-sus , famed for wealth. Croesus KREE-sus asked who was the happiest man in the world, expecting Solon SOH-lon to name him. But Solon SOH-lon said: “Call no man happy until his life is ended well.” Later, when Croesus KREE-sus lost his kingdom and faced death, he remembered Solon SOH-lon ’s words and was saved.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Later Years

English
While Solon SOH-lon was away, Athens ATH-ens soon quarreled again. Factions rose, and at last Pisistratus pie-SIS-truh-tus seized power as tyrant. Solon SOH-lon , though old, tried to resist with words and poems. He warned the Athenians not to give up freedom. He died at an advanced age, greatly honored. His ashes, it was said, were scattered on the island of Salamis SAL-ah-miss , which he had won for Athens ATH-ens .
Español
[ES placeholder]

Closing

English
Solon SOH-lon gave Athens ATH-ens freedom from debt, new laws, and the first balance between rich and poor. He refused tyranny, chose justice, and trusted the people. His wisdom guided Athens ATH-ens for centuries, and he was remembered as one of the Seven Sages of Greece.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Footnotes

English
Seisachtheia – Greek word meaning “shaking off burdens,” Solon SOH-lon ’s law that cancelled debts and freed debt‑slaves.
Español
[ES placeholder]

item.title: Chapter 8: Publicola
item.description:
Plutarch PLOO-tark ’s Life of Publicola poo-BLIK-oh-lah

(Retold for Young Readers)

Plutarch PLOO-tark Speaks

English
Plutarch PLOO-tark tells us about Publicola poo-BLIK-oh-lah , one of the founders of Rome ROHM ’s republic. He lived at the same time as Solon SOH-lon of Athens ATH-ens , and both were honored for giving laws and defending liberty.
Español
[ES placeholder]

The Fall of the Kings

English
Rome ROHM was once ruled by kings. The last, Tarquin TAR-kwin the Proud, was driven out because of his cruelty. With him fell the monarchy. Two men, Brutus BROO-tus and Collatinus COL-ah-tee-nus , became the first consuls. Publicola poo-BLIK-oh-lah soon rose to join them as one of Rome ROHM ’s leaders.
Español
[ES placeholder]

The Name “ Publicola poo-BLIK-oh-lah ”

English
At first, his enemies accused him of reaching for too much power. But when he gave up wealth and honors for the sake of the people, they named him Publicola poo-BLIK-oh-lah , meaning “friend of the people.” From then on, he lived simply, cared for justice, and loved liberty.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Laws for Freedom

English
Publicola poo-BLIK-oh-lah passed laws to protect Romans from tyranny: If anyone tried to make himself king, he could be killed without trial. The people had the right to appeal from a magistrate to the whole assembly. He lowered the fasces FAS-seez ¹, the rods and axes carried before consuls, as a sign that the people were above the rulers. He made the consulship less fearful and more beloved, showing that Rome ROHM was now ruled by its citizens.
Español
[ES placeholder]

War and Courage

English
Soon the exiled Tarquins tried to return with allies. There was treachery even among Rome ROHM ’s nobles— Brutus BROO-tus ’ own sons joined the plot! Brutus BROO-tus judged them himself and saw them executed. The people admired his stern justice. Publicola poo-BLIK-oh-lah also faced wars with the Etruscans eh-TRUS-kans and Sabines SAY-bynz . He commanded bravely, sometimes with fellow consuls, sometimes alone. In one battle he used clever planning to trap the enemy in fog and ambush, leading Rome ROHM to victory.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Stories of Kindness and Honor

English
When the Tuscan TUSS-kun king Porsena por-SAY-nah made peace, Publicola poo-BLIK-oh-lah treated him with generosity. He let his soldiers march away with their arms but no plunder, showing Roman honor. Statues were later raised in thanks for Porsena por-SAY-nah ’s goodwill. Another tale tells how Roman maidens, held hostage, escaped across the river. One girl, Cloelia KLOH-lee-ah , swam to safety. Publicola poo-BLIK-oh-lah and the Romans honored her courage with a statue on horseback by the Sacred Way SAY-krid WAY .
Español
[ES placeholder]

Death and Burial

English
Publicola poo-BLIK-oh-lah lived a life of service, never greedy for wealth. When he died, he was so poor the city paid for his burial. They gave him a grave within the city walls, near the Velia VEE-lee-uh hill, a rare honor. Roman matrons mourned for him, just as they had once mourned for Brutus BROO-tus .
Español
[ES placeholder]

Closing

English
Thus Publicola poo-BLIK-oh-lah , “friend of the people,” helped drive out kings and gave Rome ROHM its freedom. He made laws that guarded against tyranny, led armies with courage, and lived humbly. The Romans remembered him as one of the founders of their republic and a true champion of liberty.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Footnotes

English
Fasces – A bundle of rods with an axe, carried before Roman magistrates as a symbol of power.
Español
[ES placeholder]

item.title: Chapter 9: Comparison — Solon and Publicola
item.description:
Comparison of Solon SOH-lon and Publicola poo-BLIK-oh-lah

(Retold for Young Readers)

Plutarch PLOO-tark Speaks

English
Now that we have heard the lives of Solon SOH-lon of Athens ATH-ens and Publicola poo-BLIK-oh-lah of Rome ROHM , let us see how they compare.
Español
[ES placeholder]

How They Were Alike

English
Both men loved freedom. Both gave laws that protected citizens from tyranny. Solon SOH-lon gave the Athenians courts and juries. Publicola poo-BLIK-oh-lah gave Romans the right to appeal to the people. Both lowered the power of rulers so that ordinary citizens could share in government. Both said their laws came from justice, not from personal power.
Español
[ES placeholder]

How They Were Different

English
Solon SOH-lon was offered absolute power but refused it; he could have been tyrant, but chose instead to guide Athens ATH-ens with laws. Publicola poo-BLIK-oh-lah at first held great power, but he willingly gave it up; he turned kingship into consulship, making it lighter and fairer. He lowered the fasces FAS-seez ¹ before the people, showing that Rome ROHM belonged to its citizens.
Español
[ES placeholder]

On Tyranny

English
Both hated tyranny, but in different ways. Solon SOH-lon said a man who tried to seize power could only be punished after trial. Publicola poo-BLIK-oh-lah said such a man might be killed at once, without trial. So, Publicola poo-BLIK-oh-lah was even harsher against would‑be tyrants.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Which Was Greater?

English
Plutarch PLOO-tark says: Solon SOH-lon was wise in refusing absolute rule when it was offered. But Publicola poo-BLIK-oh-lah showed even greater restraint, for he already had the power of a king and chose to give it up, making Rome ROHM free. Thus both men were guardians of liberty— Solon SOH-lon by setting it up in Athens ATH-ens , and Publicola poo-BLIK-oh-lah by defending it in Rome ROHM .
Español
[ES placeholder]

Closing

English
Solon SOH-lon and Publicola poo-BLIK-oh-lah were alike in wisdom and justice, but each in his own way. Solon SOH-lon began democracy in Athens ATH-ens with laws and courts. Publicola poo-BLIK-oh-lah secured the Roman republic by humbling the power of rulers. Both are remembered as champions of freedom.
Español
[ES placeholder]

Footnotes

English
Fasces – A bundle of rods with an axe, carried before Roman magistrates as a symbol of power. Publicola poo-BLIK-oh-lah ordered them lowered in front of the Roman people to show their supremacy.
Español
[ES placeholder]

item.title: Chapter 10: Themistocles
item.description:
Plutarch PLOO-tark ’s Life of Themistocles thuh-MIS-toh-kleez

(Expanded Retelling for Young Readers)

Plutarch PLOO-tark Speaks

English
Plutarch PLOO-tark says Themistocles thuh-MIS-toh-kleez , son of Neocles NEE-oh-kleez , was one of Athens ATH-ens ’ most famous leaders. He was not born noble like Pericles PER-ih-kleez or rich like Cimon KYE-mon , but he became the savior of Greece GREESS through cleverness, courage, and ambition.
Español
[ES placeholder]

⸻

Early Life

English
As a boy, Themistocles thuh-MIS-toh-kleez was restless and bold. Other children played; he practiced speeches and imagined ruling Athens ATH-ens . His teacher said he was “a boy who will be great—either for good or ill.” He was not wealthy, but he loved honor more than gold. From youth, he cared little for music or polite manners. Instead, he trained his tongue to persuade and his mind to plan.
Español
[ES placeholder]

⸻
